major_battles.name: Bombardment of Veracruz
major_battles.description: The French Navy blockaded and bombarded the port city of Veracruz after Mexico failed to settle a financial dispute regarding damage to French property (including a pastry shop owned by a French national). The bombardment led to significant Mexican civilian casualties and the eventual surrender of Veracruz.
major_battles.outcome: French victory, Mexico forced to pay reparations

texts.name: French Government Dispatches
texts.details: The dispatches explain France's reasoning for the attack, including details of the grievances about the damage to French property.

texts.name: Mexican Records
texts.details: The records describe the Mexican perspective, which focused on the absurdity of a war being fought over a minor commercial dispute and pastry shop damages.

archaeological_evidence.description: Artifacts from the bombardment, including remnants of cannonballs and fragments from damaged buildings, have been recovered in Veracruz.
Commemorative plaques in Veracruz recall the event, humorously noting how the war began over a pastry shop dispute.

political: The war ended with Mexico agreeing to pay a large financial settlement to France, essentially resolving the pastry-related dispute. Mexico’s president, Santa Anna, was politically weakened by the event, but it did little to hinder his long-term rule.
economic: The war placed a financial strain on Mexico and became a symbolic humiliation for the country, contributing to the country’s long-term economic struggles.
historical_significance: The Pastry War is often considered one of the most absurd conflicts in history, involving a minor grievance between a pastry chef and a country. It illustrates the volatile relationships between European powers and Latin American countries in the 19th century.
